item.title: Why and how you should use AWS SDK for JavaScript (v3) on Node.js 18 | Amazon Web Services
item.description: The Node.js 18.x runtime was promoted to Active Long Term Support (LTS) on October 25th, 2022, and is now available in AWS Lambda. The AWS SDK for JavaScript (v3) is included by default in AWS Lambda Node.js 18 runtime as a convenience for developers building simpler functions. You can read about features in Node.js 18 […]

item.title: Cloud-Native Application Security - DZone Refcardz
item.description: This Refcard introduces the critical components of cloud-native application security, how to build security into the CI/CD pipeline, and core patterns and anti-patterns.

item.title: How to publish .NET 7 apps directly to Docker
item.description: With .NET 7 being around for only a couple of days now, there are plenty of new features to be played with. One of these is the actual ability of .NET's build infrastructure to directly publish your applications to a Docker container registry (or any other container registry, for that matter), without having to explicitly specify a Docker file.

item.title: Lambda Cold Starts - .NET 7 Native AOT vs .NET 6 Managed Runtime | no dogma blog
item.description: The release of .NET 7 brings with it a new way to compile and run .NET code - native AOT compilation. This post compares the cold start time of a Lambda function running on .NET 7 after native AOT compilation with the cold start time of a Lambda function running on .NET 6 with the managed runtime. The results are surprisingly good.

item.author: (Windows Insider Blog)

item.title: ECMAScript proposal: source text access for `JSON.parse()` and `JSON.stringify()`
item.description: In this blog post, we look at the ECMAScript proposal “JSON.parse source text access” by Richard Gibson and Mathias Bynens. It gives access to source text to two kinds of callbacks: Revivers, callbacks that are passed to JSON.parse() and post-process the data it parses. Replacers, callbacks that are passed to JSON.stringify() and pre-process data before it is stringified. We’ll examine how exactly that works and what you can do with this feature.

We are hackers, professionals, enthusiasts, and are passionate about life, respect, and digital freedom. We believe in peace and balance.

item.title: A Life Engineered
item.description:
Software engineers can make code do just about anything. However, they often struggle with career direction, work-life balance and finding true meaning in their jobs.
Am I hitting a bit close to home?
Let’s change that.
I have 16 years of experience at a high-performance, high-stress FAANG company as a principal engineer (top 1%). I’ve conducted over 850 technical interviews and am an expert on the promotion/growth track for high-level, non-managerial tech leadership.
It’s time to learn how to give your career and your life the same impact that your programs create for others. I’ll be there to guide you, prod you and maybe even push you out of your comfort zone.
Ready to take a smart engineering approach to your career and life?
Let’s do this.
item.author:
(•
11K views)

item.title: Decentralized Identifiers (DIDs) v1.0
item.description: Decentralized identifiers (DIDs) are a new type of identifier that enables verifiable, decentralized digital identity. A DID refers to any subject (e.g., a person, organization, thing, data model, abstract entity, etc.) as determined by the controller of the DID. In contrast to typical, federated identifiers, DIDs have been designed so that they may be decoupled from centralized registries, identity providers, and certificate authorities. Specifically, while other parties might be used to help enable the discovery of information related to a DID, the design enables the controller of a DID to prove control over it without requiring permission from any other party. DIDs are URIs that associate a DID subject with a DID document allowing trustable interactions associated with that subject.

item.title: Integrate logging in a ASP.NET Core application using Serilog and Seq
item.description: This post is about how to integrate logging in a asp.net core application using Serilog and Seq. Serilog is a logging framework for .NET. Seq is the intelligent search, analysis, and alerting server built specifically for modern structured log data. We can use Seq for free if you’re developing solo and requires a license if you’re building professionally. For more details visit seq pricing page
item.author: (Anuraj)
